p: In their analyses of AD brain tissues, Larson and coworkers also detected o- αSyn across five brain regions, including the inferior temporal gyrus (ITG), entorhinal cortex, the midfrontal gyrus (MF), the angular or inferior parietal gyrus (AG), and the calcarine cortex (CALC), encompassing all five cerebral lobes [ 108]. The accumulation of o- αSyn principally observed in the ITG, was not limited to this gyrus as other brain regions (parieto-occipital and entorhinal cortices) also displayed marked increases in o- αSyn despite a relatively-low number of specimen per clinical group per area ( n = 5–6) [ 108]. It is interesting to note that all brain areas displaying elevations of o- αSyn are part of the default mode network linked to AD, where Aβ and tau pathologies are prevalent [ 118–120]. Clearly, larger studies will be needed in the future to extensively compare regional differences within each subject.
